Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Wave Rotor Constant-Volume Combustion for Energy Efficiency and Greenhouse Gas Abatement in Gas Turbine Engines
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer Phase I project will likely be the dramatic improvement in the energy efficiency of power plants, aircraft and other vehicles, through the development of a novel pressure gain combustor for gas turbine engines. Today, these engines consume about a third of all natural gas and generate one fifth of the electricity in the US. The novel wave-rotor combustor being developed in this project will likely enable reduction of fuel consumption, carbon emission and weight of gas turbines dramatically, each by a factor of 18-20% along with lowering other emissions. Further, this research project will potentially lead to new combustion engines for lighter and more efficient road vehicles, engines for distributed generation, hybrid vehicles and robotic aircraft, larger engines for utility power generation, aviation and ships.

The objectives of this Phase I research project are to apply research on jet ignition phenomena and pulsatile flow to create the novel wave-rotor-constant-volume combustor for gas turbines. Ignition of a combustible mixture by transient high speed jets of hot reactive gas allows fast repeating combustion. Pulsatile flow results in efficient and compact gas compression and expansion processes. The new combustor circumvents the weight, vibration, noise and maintenance requirements of piston crank engines and the pressure and temperature limits of gas turbines. The concept combines multiple innovations. First, constant volume combustion creates a fundamentally more efficient thermodynamic cycle relative to current Brayton cycle gas turbine and the Otto/Diesel cycle positive displacement engines. Second pulsatile flow and pressure waves are used to further improve thermodynamics and reduce engine size and weight. Third, accelerated combustion is achieved through controlled jets of reactive gas and shock flame interaction. The research thus enables a transformative combustion process and a superior class of combustion engines, while retaining proven compact turbomachinery components.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of this STTR Phase I research project were to use jet ignition and pulsatile flow to design a novel rotating pressure-gain combustor providing a fundamentally more efficient thermodynamic cycle. It circumvents the weight, vibration, noise, and maintenance requirements of piston-crank engines and also the pressure and temperature limits of gas turbines. A full-scale “wave rotor combustor” was designed for long-duration testing at elevated temperature. It addressed potential technical challenges that may affect rotor thermal and pressure loading stresses, bearing durability and loading, clearance control to minimize leakage, fuel injection, fuel and air mixing, backflow prevention, combustion initiation, wave pattern control, minimizing outflow non-uniformity, controlling criteria emissions, various heat transfer and cooling flow challenges, and integration with the hot gas path in associated turbomachinery.

 

A prototype with key subcomponents was fabricated, assembled and tested briefly in a rig test facility, aided by a gas turbine manufacturer in a strategic partnership. Detailed test sequences were developed for startup, non-firing operation, firing operation, normal shutdown, and emergency shutdown. The rig was operated successfully numerous times in non-firing mode, and much significant and relevant data was obtained and analyzed, including vibration, pressure, and temperature levels at key locations, rotor torque, and flow rates. Failures of individual components were addressed, and a pathway to a full range of combustion tests was developed. Separately, the collaborating research institution measured ignition delay and combustion rates upon hot-jet ignition in mixtures at elevated temperature using multiple fuels in a laboratory-scale experiment, aided by computational studies.

 

The commercial potential of this innovation was evaluated to verify dramatic improvement in the energy efficiency, weight, and cost of engines for power generators, aircraft, and other vehicles. Four existing commercial gas turbine engines were evaluated closely for incorporation of pressure-gain combustion as a retrofit with potential for timely payback of investment. One of them was identified as the best candidate for initial development, based on business and technical feasibility to deliver an uprated super-efficient industrial gas turbines for distributed power generation. As a result of the intense customer discovery process, two additional applications of wave rotor technology were also considered as pivot opportunities: portable light-weight standby/back-up engine-generators, and superchargers for compact combustion engines that can overcome power and altitude limitations of recreational and unmanned aerial vehicles. Specific product concepts were developed for these two applications.

 

After thorough deliberation and evaluation, Phase II technology demonstration plans were developed for a minimally viable light-weight power generator product that uses a wave rotor combustor with curved passages to deliver shaft power for standby electricity. Issues related to component quality, manufacturing cost, system weight, and the requirements of other product system components beyond the combustion engine were assessed.  Market data was evaluated to formulate business plans over a range of time horizons, with immediate focus on the portable generator product. Third-party investment was used for business development, patent filing, and marketing activities to further discover customer needs and develop the market. An agreement to license intellectual property was negotiated and signed with a major gas turbine manufacturer, royalty-free during research and development. An SBIR Phase II proposal was submitted with plans to perform product development and testing in collaboration with strategic partners in the gas turbine and power generator industries. In addition, a proposal was also submitted to a major multinational corporation for development of a power generator product using wave rotor technology, to perform preliminary design of a complete product system as a potential Phase III activity that would leverage Phase II testing.
